title: Project Design for Bioengineering Innovation Based on Socio-Ethical Challenges: Integrating Civic Rights and Institutional Improvement Strategies

context.prior_knowledge: Biology, introductory biotechnology, basic data analysis, foundational understanding of biotechnology’s societal/ethical impacts, and basic concepts of social systems and civil rights
context.additional_context: Team-based project environment for solving real biotechnological problems. Aims to comprehensively consider not only technical solutions but also social changes, citizen rights, institutional improvements, and historical case comparisons brought by biotech innovations. Strong emphasis on interdisciplinary approaches considering political, economic, and cultural contexts

learning_goals: Learners can address real-world biotechnology issues (e.g., societal impacts of gene-editing technology) through a challenge-based approach, conducting comprehensive analyses that consider civic rights and cultural contexts

Learners can design data-driven decision-making processes using digital tools, incorporating the economic, political, and institutional contexts of biotechnology and proposing directions for systemic improvement

In 4-member teams, learners analyze one real-world biotechnology case (e.g., issues in applying gene-editing technology) and propose actionable creative solutions through a three-stage collaborative process: brainstorming → prototype design → solution presentation. They must achieve over 80 points on the evaluation rubric (Creativity 30%, Collaboration Efficiency 30%, Feasibility 40%). This process includes a holistic analysis of the technology’s ethical/social impacts and historical case comparisons
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
